intro: Podocarpus totara var. waihoensis, commonly known as the Waiho totara, is a rare and endemic species native to the forests of New Zealand. It is a coniferous evergreen tree belonging to the Podocarpaceae family, characterized by its needle-like leaves and cone-bearing reproductive structures. The tree typically grows in coastal and lowland forest habitats, often forming dense stands in the North Island. Its bark is thick and fissured, providing structural support and protection against environmental stressors. This variant is distinguished by its unique leaf morphology and is of significant ecological and cultural importance to Māori communities.
